module.p: air on, upon is the (non-leniting) superessive preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the superessive preposition is simply air –
air bòrd on a table
air aibhnichean on rivers
air Neaptun on Neptune
air trì leapannan on three beds

Unlike with some other prepositions, there is no special form of air used before the definite article –
air an talamh on the ground
air a’ bhòrd on the table
air na h-itealain on the airplanes

Moreover, there are no fused forms with air and a possessive determiner –
air mo cheann on my head
air do bhòrd on your table
air a h-ùbhlan on her apples
air a chois on his foot
air ar sgeilpean on our shelves
air bhur coin on your dogs
air an taighean on their houses
air am fearann on their land

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of air mi, air thu, ... , air iad –
orm on me
ort on you
oirre on her/it
air on him/it
oirnn on us
oirbh on you
orra on them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. air mise, air thusa, ... , air iadsan) –
ormsa on me
ortsa on you
oirrese on her/it
airsan on him/it
oirnne on us
oirbhse on you
orrasan on them
Note that the form airsan breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – air-san.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. air mi fhìn, air thu fhèin, ... air iad fhèin) –
orm fhìn on myself
ort fhèin on yourself
oirre fhèin on herself/itself
air fhèin on himself/itself
oirnn fhìn on ourselves
oirbh fhèin on yourself
orra fhèin on themselves

One common use of the preposition air is to introduce the predicate of the verb bi –
Tha Seònaid air an taigh sholais. Shona is at the lighthouse.
Tha each ùr orm. We have a new horse.
Some specific subtypes of predicate relation are described in the following sections.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Tha [an salann] shuas air an sgeilp sin.
[The salt] is up there on that shelf. td. 35

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Tha còta snog oirre. Tha peitean air Iain. Tha brògan àrda orra. Tha ad air.
She is wearing a nice coat. John is wearing a jumper. They are wearing boots. He is wearing a hat. td. 64

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Dè an t-ainm a tha ort? / C’ ainm a tha ort? Is e Iain (an t-ainm) a tha orm.
What is your name? John is my name. td. 64

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Tha an t-acras orm. Tha am pathadh ort. Tha an cnatan air. Tha an t-eagal oirre. Tha cabhag oirnn.
I am hungry. You are thirsty. He has a cold. She is afraid. We are in a hurry. td. 64
Tha an cadal orm agus is beag orm plèanaichean co-dhiù.
I am sleepy and I don’t like planes anyway. td. 66 deps|complement|human|patient, uses|predicate|affliction|idiom

When the preposition air governs an infinitive (verbal noun), it generally indicates retrospective aspect, similar in some ways to the English ‘perfect tenses’ –
Tha Raonaid air rud a dhèanamh Rachel has done something

Basic pattern –
Tha Seumas air èirigh James has risen

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha iad air falbh.
They have gone. td. 11
Tha iad air tighinn dhachaigh.
They have come home. td. 22
Bha Uilleam air tilleadh. / Bidh iad air a dhol a-mach. / Bhiodh Màiri air seinn.
William had returned. / They will have gone out. / Mary would have sung. td. 158–9

Basic pattern –
Tha Raonaid air na balaich a phògadh Rachel has kissed the boys

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Bha mi air an doras a dhùnadh.
I had closed the door. td. 11
Tha Anna air an t-uisge a òl. / Bha Niall air Gàidhlig a ionnsachadh. / Bidh Dàibhidh air an doras a pheantadh. / Bhiodh Calum air leabhar a cheannach. / Tha Raibeart air an cù a bhiadhadh mar-thà. / Tha Anna air am borbair a phàigheadh.
Ann has drunk the water. / Neil has learnt Gaelic. / David will have painted the door. / Calum would have bought a book. / Robert has fed the dog already. / Ann has paid the hairdresser. td. 158–9
A bheil thu air an iuchair a bhriseadh?
Have you broken the key? td. 22

Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. [...] Dé na rudan a dh’ fhaodadh sinn iarraidh? [...] Chan eil an sin ach rud no dhà a dh’ fhaodamaid iarraidh. Tha Comunn nan Croitearan air nì de ’n t-seòrsa so iarraidh mar tha, air a’ Bh.B.C. Thug sin togail inntinn dhuinn. Có a nis a chuireas fead chruaidh ann an cluais Luchd an Ionmhais ann a Westminster?
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. [...] What are the things that we could demand? [...] Those are just a couple of things that we could demand. The Crofters’ Society has demanded something of this kind already, on the BBC. That has given us inspiration. Who now will put a hard whistle [?] in the ear of the Finance People in Westminster? td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’

Other examples from modern usage –
[...] B’ e Rob a b’ òige agus lean e an sgoil. Nuair a ràinig e an t-oilthigh bha càch airson gun ionnsaicheadh e cunntasachd, a bhiodh feumail anns a’ mhalairt, ach ’s ann a bha ùidh-san ann an ealain. Dh’fhàg e an t-oilthigh agus chaidh e do sgoil ealain. Bha cuibhreann aige bho athair a bha tuilleadh ’s gu leòr airson fheumalachd ged a bha e dèidheil air a’ bhotal, agus cha robh e a’ dèanamh spàirn sam bith airson faighinn air adhart san t-saoghal. Bhiodh e a’ dèanamh sgrùdadh ealain do phàipear-naidheachd agus corra dhealbh, ach bha a chaitheamh-beatha glè fhada bho ùpraid muinntir Thòmais, no ‘mafia’ Thòmais, mar a chanadh e fhèin. Nuair a dh’innis e gu robh e air nighean a thoirt a dh’fhuireach còmhla ris, thuirt Tòmas ri càch, [...] ’S ann an taigh Aonghais a’ Bhàillidh – caraid a bha còmhla ris san sgoil – a bhiodh Rob a’ fuireach nuair a bhiodh e aig an taigh. Bha muinntir Thòmais air an clachan fhàgail o chionn fhada. [...]
[...] Rob was the youngest [in the family] and he stayed on at school. When he reached the university the others wanted him to learn accountancy, which would be useful in the business, but his interest was in art. He left the university and went to an art school. He had an allowance from his father which more more than enough for his needs even though he was fond of the bottle, and he was not making any effort to get on in the world. He would be making art reviews for a newspaper and some pictures, but his way of life was very far from the commotion of Thomas’ people, or Thomas’ ‘mafia’, as he would say himself. When he announced that he had brought a girl to live with him, Thomas said to the others, [...] It was in Angus of the Baillie’s house – a friend who was with him in the school – that Rob would be staying when he would be at home. Thomàs’ [Rob’s father] people had left the village long before. [...] td. 5

Basic pattern –
Tha Raonaid air mo phògadh Rachel has kissed me

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha iad air fhaicinn. / Bha iad air am moladh.
They have seen him. / They had praised them. td. 11
Tha e air a bhriseadh. / Tha e air a briseadh. / Tha e air mo shàbhaladh a-rithist.
He has broken him/it [masc.] / He has broken her/it [fem.] / He has saved me again. td. 22
Tha mi air an dèanamh. / Bha na fèidh air a ghluasad.
I have done them. / The deer had moved it. td. 133

When the possessive determiner agrees with the subject in person, number and gender, a passive-like sense is possible –
Tha rud air a dhèanamh Something has been done
Tha rudan air an dèanamh Things have been done

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha am feur air a ghearradh. / Bha an t-uisge beatha air a òl uile gu lèir. / Cha robh na bàtaichean air an càradh. / Bha an càr air a ghoid. / Bha an t-àite air a lìonadh le uisge.
The grass is [has been] cut. / The whisky was all [had all been] drunk. / The boats were not [had not been] fixed. / The car was [had been] stolen. / The place was [had been] filled with water. td. 171–2
Bha na lèintean air an dèanamh anns na h-Innsean. / Tha an litir air a taidhpeadh a-nise. / Bidh aon doras air a dhùnadh. / Bha mi air mo leòn gu dona. / Tha na bagaichean air an dèanamh. / Bha am bogsa air a ghluasad. / Bha sibh air ur cumail a-mach.
The shirts have been made in the Islands. / The letter has been typed now. / One door will have been closed. / I had been hurt badly. I had hurt myself badly. / The bags have been made. / The box had been moved. / You had been kept out. td. 133

Some instances are ambiguous between passive-like and active retrospective readings, at least in isolation –
Bha iad air am moladh.
They had been praised. They had praised them. td. 11
Bha am fiadh air a mharbhadh. / An robh Niall air a bhualadh? / An robh Mòrag air a taghadh?
The deer was [had been] killed. The deer had killed him. / Was Neil [had Neil been] hit? Had Neil hit him? / Was Morag [had Morag been] (s)elected? Had Morag (s)elected her? td. 171–2
Bha iad uile air an sàbhaladh.
They were all [had all been] saved. They had all saved them. td. 22
Bha duine air a mharbhadh.
A man has been killed. A man has killed him/it. td. 133

Examples with an explicit agent –
Bha Iain air a bhualadh aca.
John was [had been] hit by them. td. 173

Examples from Gairm –
Tha An Comunn Gaidhealach a’ bruidhinn air Seanaileir ùr a thaghadh a bhios os cionn obair a’ Chomuinn. [...] Cha b’ fhuilear do dhuine de ’n t-seòrsa so tomhas mhath de chumhachd a bhith aige. Cha dean math dha a bhith air a shlaodadh aig tòin Coimitidh, ach feumaidh an Coimitidh earbsa a bhith aca ás.
The Highland Society is talking about choosing a new General who will oversee the Society’s work. [...] A person of this kind would have to have a good measure of power. It would do him no good to have been dragged along by the Committee ??, but the Committee must have trust in him. td. 105, ‘Air an Spiris’
Anns na ràithean ’s na bliadhnachan a tha air thoiseach oirnn, tha fhios gun dig iomadh atharrachadh air Roinn na Gàidhlig sa’ Bh.B.C. [...] Mar a bhios obair a’ Bh.B.C. a’ leudachadh anns a’ Ghaidhealtachd—agus tha fhios gun tachair so leis na stéiseanan ùra a thathas a’ togail—bithidh sùil againn ri daoine ùra ’s ri dòighean ùra. Bhitheadh e nàdurrach agus fallain nam biodh barrachd phrógraman air an deilbh air a’ Ghaidhealtachd fhéin, agus gum biodh pàirt de ’n obair so air a chur an tairgse nan Gaidheal ’s nan Gall air Galldachd. [...]
During the seasons and the years that are ahead of us, it is known that many changes will come to the Gaelic Department of the BBC. [...] As the work of the BBC will be expanding in the Highlands – and it is known that this will happen with the new stations that are being established – we will be expecting new people and new methods. It would be natural and healthy if more programmes were [had been] produced in the Highlands itself, and [if] some of this work were [had ben] offered to Gaels and non-Gaels in the Lowlands. [...] td. 297, ‘Air an Spiris’ passive

Biblical examples –
[...] Agus labhair righ na h-Eiphit re mnaibh-glùine nan Eabhruidheach [...] Agus thubhairt e, ’Nuair a ni sibh gnìomh mnà-glùine do na mnaibh Eabhruidheach, agus a chi sibh iad air na stòlaibh; ma’s mac a bhios ann, ’an sin marbhaidh sibh e, ach ma’s nighean a bhios ann, bithidh si beo. Ach bha eagal Dé air na mnaibh-glùine, agus cha d’rinn iad mar a dh’àithn righ na h-Eiphit dhoibh, ach ghleidh iad a’ chlann mhac beo. Agus ghairm righ na h-Eiphit air na mnaibh-glùine, agus thubhairt e riu, C’ar son a rinn sibh an ni so, agus a ghleidh sibh a’ chlann mhac beo? Agus thubhairt na mnài-ghlùine re Pharaoh, A chionn nach ’eil na mnài Eabhruidheach mar na mnài Eiphiteach: oir tha iad féin beothail, agus air an aisead mu’n d’thig na mnài-ghlùine a steach d’an ionnsuidh. Uime sin bhuin Dia gu math ris na mnaibh-glùine: agus rinneadh an sluagh lìonmhor, agus dh’fhàs iad ro-chumhachdach. [...]
[...] And the king of Egypt spake to the Hebrew midwives [...] And he said, When ye do the office of a midwife to the Hebrew women, and see them upon the stools; if it be a son, then ye shall kill him: but if it be a daughter, then she shall live. But the midwives feared God, and did not as the king of Egypt commanded them, but saved the men children alive. And the king of Egypt called for the midwives, and said unto them, Why have ye done this thing, and have saved the men children alive? And the midwives said unto Pharaoh, Because the Hebrew women are not as the Egyptian women; for they are lively, and are delivered ere the midwives come in unto them. Therefore God dealt well with the midwives: and the people multiplied, and waxed very mighty. [...] Ecsodus I.15–20
cf. dìreach

Examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Tha Màiri dìreach air tighinn. / Tha iad dìreach air falbh. / Tha iad dìreach air an doras a dhùnadh.
Mary has just come. / They have just left. / They have just closed the door. td. 160

The modern Gaelic preposition is a fusion of three different Old Gaelic prepositions –
the leniting, accusative/dative-governing preposition ar in front of, for (the sake of), on account of
the non-mutating, accusative/dative-governing preposition for on, over
the nasalising, dative-governing preposition íar after (temporal), according to
